html.p: The following is a summary of the reading from the textbook to give you an idea of what is expected to know before coming to class. It does not replace reading the textbook.
Conductors have the following basic properties (refer to 3.3 in textbook 3-16):
(1) The electric field is zero inside a conductor. (3-16)
(2) Any net charge must reside on the surface.
(3) The tangential component of [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] is zero on the surface of a conductor. (3-17)
(4) [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] is normal to the surface just outside the conductor. (3-18)
(5) The discontinuity in the normal component of the electric field across the conductor is proportional to the surface charge density.(3-19)
Electrostatic tention on a conducting surface is
[mathjax]P = \frac{F}{A} = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\varepsilon_0} = \frac{1}{2} \varepsilon(\frac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_0})^2 = \frac{1}{2} \varepsilon_0E^2[/mathjax]

b.a: Deriving Electric Field from the Electric Potential (refer to 4.4 in textbook 4-12)

html.p: We know that the electric potential at a point P is
[mathjax]V_{P} =-\int \nolimits _{\infty }^{P} \vec{E}\cdot d\vec{s}, \:\:\:\:V(\infty )=0 [/mathjax]
If we consider two points that are separated by a small distance [mathjaxinline]d\vec{\vec{s}}[/mathjaxinline] , the following differential form is obtained:
[mathjax]dV=-\vec{E}\cdot d\vec{s}[/mathjax]
Therefore
[mathjax]E_{x} =-\frac{\partial V}{\partial x} ,\, \, \, \, E_{y} =-\frac{\partial V}{\partial y} ,\, \, \, \, \, E_{z} =-\frac{\partial V}{\partial z}[/mathjax]

By introducing a differential quantity called the del (gradient) operator [mathjaxinline]\nabla \equiv \frac{\partial }{\partial x}\hat{i} +\frac{\partial }{\partial y} \hat{j}\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\hat{k}[/mathjaxinline] the electric field can be written as
[mathjax]\vec{E}=E_{x}\hat{i} +E_{y}\hat{j} +E_{z}\hat{k} =-\left( \frac{\partial V}{\partial x} \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} \, \, +\frac{\partial V}{\partial z} \right) =-\nabla V.[/mathjax]

b.a: Gradients and Equipotentials (refer to 4.5 in textbook 4-13)

html.p: Suppose a system in two dimensions has an electric potential [mathjaxinline]V(x,y)[/mathjaxinline] . The curves characterized by constant [mathjaxinline]V(x,y)[/mathjaxinline] are called equipotential curves. Examples of equipotential curves are depicted in Figure 4.5.1 below.

In three dimensions, surfaces such that [mathjaxinline]V(x,y,z)=\text {constant}[/mathjaxinline] are called equipotential surfaces. Because [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}=-\nabla V,[/mathjaxinline] we can show that the direction of [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] at a point is always perpendicular to the equipotential through that point. We shall show this in two dimensions. Generalization to three dimensions is straightforward.

Referring to Figure 4.5.2, let the potential at a point [mathjaxinline]P(x,y)[/mathjaxinline] be [mathjaxinline]V(x,y)[/mathjaxinline] . The potential difference [mathjaxinline]dV[/mathjaxinline] between [mathjaxinline]P(x,y)[/mathjaxinline] and a neighboring point is [mathjaxinline]dV=(\nabla V)\cdot d\text {s} =-\vec{E}\cdot d\text {s}[/mathjaxinline] (refer to 4.5.2 in textbook 4-14)

p.center: Figure 4.5.2 Change in V when moving from one equipotential curve to another

html.p: If the displacement [mathjaxinline]d\vec{s}[/mathjaxinline] is along the tangent to the equipotential curve that passes through the point [mathjaxinline]P[/mathjaxinline] with coordinates [mathjaxinline](x,y)[/mathjaxinline] , then [mathjaxinline]dV=0[/mathjaxinline] because V is constant everywhere on that curve. This implies that [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}\bot d\vec{s}[/mathjaxinline] along the equipotential curve. That is, [mathjaxinline]\vec{E}[/mathjaxinline] is perpendicular to the equipotential.
Note that the surface of a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium is an equipotential surface. (Refer to 4.5.1 in textbook 4-16)
The properties of equipotential surfaces can be summarized as follows:
(i) The electric field lines are perpendicular to the equipotentials and point from higher to lower potentials.
(ii) By symmetry, the equipotential surfaces produced by a point charge form a family of concentric spheres, and for constant electric field, a family of planes perpendicular to the field lines.
(iii) The tangential component of the electric field along the equipotential surface is zero, otherwise non-vanishing work would be done to move a charge from one point on the surface to the other.
(iv) No work is required to move a particle along an equipotential surface.

b.a: Continuous Symmetric Charge Distributions (refer to 4.6 in textbook 4-17)

html.p: The electric potential due to a continuous charge distribution is
[mathjax]V=\frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon _{0} } \int \nolimits _{}^{}\frac{dq}{r}[/mathjax]
